messages.text: It should automatically detect a project.toml file in the working directory. If not, you can click on the Julia environment tab on the bottom and set it to the path you want. Or else I think there’s an option you can set in the directory .vscode/settings.json (you can make one of these if it isn’t already there)

messages.text: That's because we don't start the REPL through your shell. I think your way should work fine if you start VSCode from bash though. Otherwise use the `terminal.integrated.env.linux` setting (or whatever OS you're on).

messages.text:
Do you mean a Python virtualenv?
```ENV["PYCALL_JL_RUNTIME_PYTHON"] =  pwd() * "/bin/python3"

using PyCall

torch = pyimport("torch")```
Posting in the hopes someone will correct me if there's a better way.

root.text: Hey everyone, apologies if this is answered somewhere. Is there a way to set up vscode to work with a virtual environment? I assume there's a json config file somewhere, but I'm not finding the details online.

elements.text: Hey everyone, apologies if this is answered somewhere. Is there a way to set up vscode to work with a virtual environment? I assume there's a json config file somewhere, but I'm not finding the details online.
Do you mean a Python virtualenv?

ENV["PYCALL_JL_RUNTIME_PYTHON"] =  pwd() * "/bin/python3"

using PyCall

torch = pyimport("torch")
Posting in the hopes someone will correct me if there's a better way.

messages.text: Hey folks, I am new to vscode and the julia extension as well. I was just following along in the video tutorial from a few months ago, and I realize that I don't seem to get the inline showing of the code results. So I write a line of code like `cars = dataset("cars")`, and I run that line of code, in my case `ctrl+c ctrl+j` because I set the key binding. I see the dataframe in the repl window, but not next to the actual line of code. Also if I hover over the line of code, I don't see any variable results, etc. Did I set something up wrong or is there someway to enable that setting?

[ Info: loading Revise```
I've got the same startup I've had for ages, is there some change needed now?

```atreplinit() do repl
    @info "Loading OhMyREPL"
    @eval using OhMyREPL

    try
        @info "loading Revise"
        @eval using Revise
        @async Revise.wait_steal_repl_backend()
    catch e
        @warn("unable to load Revise", e)
    end
end```
This is julia 1.6-rc1

messages.text:
I am getting an error that only happens in the REPL spawned by VSCode, not in the usual REPL. I am trying out some Luxor.jl code to create animations. This one, for instance:
```# Adapted from [Cormullian's Slackmojiv's post](<https://cormullion.github.io/pages/2019-06-23-slackmojif/>)
using Luxor

function frame(scene, framenumber)
    nfn = rescale(framenumber, scene.framerange.start, scene.framerange.stop)
    rotate(π*sin(nfn * 2π))
    juliacircles(18)
end

size = 64
mymovie = Movie(size, size, "mymovie")
animate(mymovie, [Scene(mymovie, frame, 1:60)],
    creategif=true, pathname="juliafullrocker$(size)x$(size).gif")```
In the REPL, there is no problem, and the animated gif is created. But when I run it from inside vscode, I get the error
```┌ Info: Frames for animation "mymovie" are being stored in directory: 
└        /var/folders/yj/2q95f5rd57n7_6_q2jym158w0000gn/T/jl_zbLIzB
┌ Warning: Movie framerange is longer than scene frame range: 
│        1:250 > 60
└ @ Luxor ~/.julia/packages/Luxor/XSNgj/src/animate.jl:185
┌ Info: ... 60 frames saved in directory:
└        /var/folders/yj/2q95f5rd57n7_6_q2jym158w0000gn/T/jl_zbLIzB
ERROR: LoadError: IOError: could not spawn `ffmpeg -loglevel panic -framerate 30 -f image2 -i /var/folders/yj/2q95f5rd57n7_6_q2jym158w0000gn/T/jl_zbLIzB/%10d.png -filter_complex '[0:v] split [a][b]; [a] palettegen=stats_mode=full:reserve_transparent=on:transparency_color=FFFFFF [p]; [b][p] paletteuse=new=1:alpha_threshold=128' -y /var/folders/yj/2q95f5rd57n7_6_q2jym158w0000gn/T/jl_zbLIzB/mymovie.gif`: no such file or directory (ENOENT)
Stacktrace:
 [1] _spawn_primitive(::String, ::Cmd, ::Array{Any,1}) at ./process.jl:99
 [2] #585 at ./process.jl:112 [inlined]
 [3] setup_stdios(::Base.var"#585#586"{Cmd}, ::Array{Any,1}) at ./process.jl:196
 [4] _spawn at ./process.jl:111 [inlined]
 [5] run(::Cmd; wait::Bool) at ./process.jl:439
 [6] run at ./process.jl:438 [inlined]
 [7] animate(::Movie, ::Array{Scene,1}; creategif::Bool, framerate::Int64, pathname::String, tempdirectory::String, usenewffmpeg::Bool) at /Users/rrosa/.julia/packages/Luxor/XSNgj/src/animate.jl:211
 [8] top-level scope at /Users/rrosa/Documents/git_repositories/julia/julia_random_stuff/src/julia_rocker.jl:16
in expression starting at /Users/rrosa/Documents/git_repositories/julia/julia_random_stuff/src/julia_rocker.jl:16```
When I copy the ffmpeg command and run it directly in the shell, it works too.

Is that due to how the VSCode Julia extension handles this or is it something else?

messages.text: I figured (with a little help from friends), that the problem with vscode/Luxor is a PATH thing. The REPL that vscode/julia extension spawns when I run the code doesn’t have the PATH environmental variable set. How can I make the extension pick up the PATH variable set by the shell?

yeah Im just trying to figure out what processes that look like this:
```/home/kwd/.vscode-server/bin/f30a9b73e8ffc278e71575118b6bf568f04587c8/node /home/kwd/.vscode-server/bin/f30a9b73e8ffc278e71575118b6bf568f04587c8/out/bootstrap-fork --type=extensionHost --uriTransformerPath=/home/kwd/.vscode-server/bin/f30a9b73e8ffc278e71575118b6bf568f04587c8/out/vs/server/uriTransformer.js```
are doing.  As soon as I connect remotely via vs-code remote these spin up on the host machine and they use a fair bit of cpu, even when Im doing nothing.  Ive messed with the Remote SSH settings and nothing changes.  The only hint I can find from googling around is that people started seeingsomething like this maybe after they changed node versions.  That particular binary is v 12.18.3 while I have nodejs v15.8.0 on the machine.

messages.text:
Is there any mmapping that goes on in the language server process? I’m trying to reconcile why:
- Task manager tells me the process is taking up 3GB, within 2 mins of starting up
- The LanguageServer and SymbolServer modules only having `summarysize` of up to tens of MiB (probed here <https://github.com/julia-vscode/julia-vscode/pull/2001>)
- MacOS’s “Instruments” probing app claiming that the backend julia process is only creating ~200 MiB of persistent memory usage during the time period where memory usage rises from 200MB to 3 GB

elements.text:

- The LanguageServer and SymbolServer modules only having
summarysize
of up to tens of MiB (probed here

- MacOS’s “Instruments” probing app claiming that the backend julia process is only creating ~200 MiB of persistent memory usage during the time period where memory usage rises from 200MB to 3 GB

messages.text:
Hello everyone, before I ask my question, just wanted to say what a fantastic job the VS Code Julia extension team have been doing!

Now the issue: does anyone else experience repeated `Fetching`, `Progress` or `Downloading` lines when installing packages in the VS Code REPL? It seems each time the progress bar adds another `=` to the `===>`, it gets added to a new line as opposed to staying on the same line. Attached should be a sample screenshot I took (I'm still kinda new to Slack). I'm on a brand new Windows laptop (haven't tried this in Linux yet), with the following versions of things:
• Julia v1.6.0-rc1
• VS Code 1.54.1
• Julia Extension 1.1.32
• let me know if other info is needed

messages.text: I've seen that happen before, but could never reliably reproduce it. You can try to horiziontally resize the terminal in case there's some rounding/measurement error that causes a discrepancy between the reported and actual terminal widths

elements.text: I've seen that happen before, but could never reliably reproduce it. You can try to horiziontally resize the terminal in case there's some rounding/measurement error that causes a discrepancy between the reported and actual terminal widths

messages.text: Nice, that helped, widening the terminal window. Is that more of a VS Code issue, or Julia Extension issue? I don't mind it much myself, but as someone who's been trying to convince my coworkers to give Julia a try for the past two years, I worry about potential first impression issues that might throw off a newbie trying Julia for the first time. The whole Pkg experience has improved so much in recent releases, and the VS Code extension keeps getting better and better -- I hope this doesn't sound too cheesy, but I want the whole Julia experience to be the best it can be.

messages.text:
I'm still struggling to figure out how to get VSCode's julia to inherit my environment. From the VS code terminal:

```echo $PATH
/home/linuxbrew/.linuxbrew/bin:/opt/miniconda3/bin:/home/kevin/.vscode-server/bin/f30a9b73e8ffc278e71575118b6bf568f04587c8/bin:/usr/local/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin:/sbin:/bin:/usr/games:/home/kevin/bin:/home/kevin/.local/bin```
but from julia:

```ENV["PATH"]
"/home/kevin/.vscode-server/bin/f30a9b73e8ffc278e71575118b6bf568f04587c8/bin:/usr/local/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin:/sbin:/bin:/usr/games"```
A julia REPL opened from the terminal has `ENV["PATH"]` identical to `echo $PATH`

messages.text:
Hi, I have recently been experimenting with my development environment from text editor + terminal to VS Code and I have the following three issues that were easy with my old setup and I am not sure what is the best practice under VS Code for them:
1. Is it possible to quickly inform VS Code about the folder in which I want to launch Julia REPL?
2. Is it possible to quickly switch which version of Julia is launched with Julia REPL (I need to run Julia 1.0, stable release, and nightly)?
3. Can I have those three Julia REPL sessions (described in point 2) running at the same time and send code to the "active one"?
(these requirements are probably not important for project work, but they are important for me for package development work, and I would prefer to a single environment for both cases). Thank you!

elements.text: Hi, I have recently been experimenting with my development environment from text editor + terminal to VS Code and I have the following three issues that were easy with my old setup and I am not sure what is the best practice under VS Code for them:
Is it possible to quickly inform VS Code about the folder in which I want to launch Julia REPL?
Is it possible to quickly switch which version of Julia is launched with Julia REPL (I need to run Julia 1.0, stable release, and nightly)?
Can I have those three Julia REPL sessions (described in point 2) running at the same time and send code to the "active one"?
(these requirements are probably not important for project work, but they are important for me for package development work, and I would prefer to a single environment for both cases). Thank you!

messages.text:
1. We start the REPL in the topmost workspace folder, but you can easily `cd` to a different dir with `Alt-J Alt-C` or right clicking on a file/dir.
2. No, not really. You need to change the Julia path in the settings.
3. No. We currently only have one integrated REPL.

elements.text: 1. We start the REPL in the topmost workspace folder, but you can easily
cd
to a different dir with
Alt-J Alt-C

or right clicking on a file/dir.
2. No, not really. You need to change the Julia path in the settings.
3. No. We currently only have one integrated REPL.

messages.text:
That said, I can think of two workarounds:
1. Do development in the integrated REPL session on a fixed Julia version and create tasks for running tests on the other two versions (or just start them in separate integrated terminals and call `Pkg.test` manually)
2. There's an extension that lets you send the current line to the active terminal (doesn't select the current code block though).

elements.text:
That said, I can think of two workarounds:
1. Do development in the integrated REPL session on a fixed Julia version and create tasks for running tests on the other two versions (or just start them in separate integrated terminals and call
Pkg.test

manually)
2. There's an extension that lets you send the current line to the active terminal (doesn't select the current code block though).

messages.text:
Not sure how many people are using native notebooks here…it seems when running a (native) jupyter notebook with Julia kernel, the REPL and the kernel are two separate sessions, so the shortcut shift-enter while editing will send the current line to the REPL instead of the kernel for the notebook, which is a bit annoying.
For now I I just simply change the shortcut so shift-enter always runs the cell by the kernel. I was wondering if we are going to integrate these different sessions or will keep it as it is?

elements.text:
Not sure how many people are using native notebooks here…it seems when running a (native) jupyter notebook with Julia kernel, the REPL and the kernel are two separate sessions, so the shortcut shift-enter while editing will send the current line to the REPL instead of the kernel for the notebook, which is a bit annoying.
For now I I just simply change the shortcut so shift-enter always runs the cell by the kernel. I was wondering if we are going to integrate these different sessions or will keep it as it is?

messages.text: We're currently working on the whole native notebook integration story, so hopefully that will get a lot better soonish. The plan is to have a separate kernel per notebook, so essentially when you are in a notebook, there won't be any connection to the REPL.

elements.text: We're currently working on the whole native notebook integration story, so hopefully that will get a lot better soonish. The plan is to have a separate kernel per notebook, so essentially when you are in a notebook, there won't be any connection to the REPL.

messages.text: So we are working on the whole notebook side of things, and there is an easy way that the 500+ folks in this channel can help us with that: the feedback I got from the team at MS that is working on the Jupyter extension is that they prioritize _very_ much by likes on github issues. So if we want them to sort something out on the Jupyter extension end of things, the best thing to do is to upvote such an issue with likes (NOT comments). So that is where you all can help :slightly_smiling_face: First case: <https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-jupyter/issues/5126>

elements.text: So we are working on the whole notebook side of things, and there is an easy way that the 500+ folks in this channel can help us with that: the feedback I got from the team at MS that is working on the Jupyter extension is that they prioritize
very

much by likes on github issues. So if we want them to sort something out on the Jupyter extension end of things, the best thing to do is to upvote such an issue with likes (NOT comments). So that is where you all can help
First case:

messages.text: I'll try to not do this too often, but I will going forward from time to time ask for help with upvoting issues :slightly_smiling_face:

messages.text:
Hey folks. I keep getting this strange error when I try to evaluate a line of code with `CTRL-Enter`. The message is
```syntax: extra token "]" after end of expression```
But the error does not make sense. For example, if I evaluate a line of code like `rosenbrock(x,p) =  (p[1] - x[1])^2 + p[2] * (x[2] - x[1]^2)^2`, I get this same error. If I eval the same code in the terminal, it is just fine. So not sure why an extra `]` is getting appended, or something strange is happening. anyone else have this issue?

attachments.text: @aviatesk do you have that list somewhere? I’d be very interested to take a look. What is a good place to have these discussions for individual features? My sense is that the one feature that really can’t be implemented with the current VS Code API is the inline viewing of eval results. MS had been working on an API for that, but it is unclear to me how much they are pushing that right now. Having said that, we are getting a full notebook UI, which should make for a very Jupyter like experienc...
attachments.fallback: JuliaLang: Github annouced codespace. does it mean Atom is now abandoned?

messages.text: No work on that file format at the moment, and I'm not sure I'll revive it. At the moment we are focusing on getting first class Jupyter Notebook into the extension, and much of the work on that PR has moved over to that effort.
